awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Community Integration Platform for Health Science Education of Social Emotional Intelligence through Collaborative Mixed Reality
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to maximize competitiveness, the United States must create sustainable education pathways to develop workforce readiness through life-long education and training using innovative educational technologies. This project leverages a unique collaboration between Richardson Independent School District (RISD) and the Methodist Richardson Medical Center (MRMC) to enable students to graduate from high school with entry-level medical certifications in fields such as Pharmacy Tech, EKG Technician or Clinical Medical Assistant and start working immediately after high school. However, a key component to readiness for these workers is social emotional intelligence (SEI) or the ability to successfully handle patient/family/caregiver situations; develop cultural empathy; and strengthen professional stamina. Skills in these areas will help these workers gain employment and stay employed. In order to get this real-life experience, students traditionally do clinical rotations in medical settings. However, clinical experiences are limited, not all students can participate, and students sometimes do not get enough hospital experience to develop SEI. Through this planning grant, the project team will design a platform to provide education that will expand on the clinical educational opportunities available to students with complementary networked and collaborative virtual experiences designed to fill SEI educational gaps and facilitate student learning through both high school faculty and hospital staff. 

In this planning grant, an established group of experts in both healthcare curriculum and learning science methodology will confirm the required SEI skills necessary for the students to develop and explore the immersive media that will best be able to provide these experiences, while heavily considering the social learning or group and observational educational opportunities between faculty, students and hospital staff. From a technology perspective, the project planning team will explore using educational video game environments, virtual humans, and similar collaborative mixed reality over high speed networks such as the Richardson US Ignite Smart Gigabit Community. This project will define mixed reality as the appropriate balance of advanced digital technology emphasizing augmented and virtual reality. The project will also design the metrics for determining the platform’s viability and usability. A potential approach is design-based research, which provides a basis for cross-disciplinary work. This iterative research approach will integrate key community stakeholders such as students, teachers and working professionals; learning context, e.g. hospital culture; and integration of these factors with technology research. This research will contribute to new types of learning paradigms that are dynamic, immersive, engaging and distributable– thus enabling a unique type of educational platform for sustaining critical STEM educational pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Researchers from the Center for Simulation and Synthetic Humans at the University of Texas at Dallas (The Center) worked closely with partners from Richardson Independent School District (RISD), Methodist Richardson Medical Center (MRMC), and Texas Woman's University (TWU) to plan and develop a proposal for the Community Integration Platform for Health Science Education of Social Emotional Intelligence through Collaborative Mixed Reality. The platform focuses on building resiliency in high school students from the Richardson Healthcare Career Academy (RHCA) in Richardson, Texas through social emotional intelligence (SEI) education in both virtual and real modalities. The platform will connect a digital domain in which students roleplay virtual hospital scenarios with the students’ live hospital clinical rotations -- forming a metaverse that encompasses both the virtual and physical realms. As students participate in the platform, SEI competencies will be learned, practiced  and assessed in both the virtual and live realms in order to improve resiliency and communication capabilities. Curriculum,  emotional state and SEI monitoring will be achieved through virtual reality (VR) and biometric sensors that will gather student real-time data in the classroom and the hospital-based clinical rotations. These research factors also link the virtual and real learning environments. 

Five research goals were met. The first was to develop a definition of the problem that the platform would target, working to identify the SEI curriculum needs for the RHCA’s Patient Care Technician certification program, and selecting an appropriate approach to organize the platform’s logistical needs. In the second goal, The Center and community partners analyzed potential psychology and social science-related research supported by the platform with social and learning impact. Two frameworks discovered were the work-based learning (WBL) framework and The Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning (CASEL) framework. For the third goal, A research design was developed exploring a longitudinal cohort-driven concept in which the platform would evolve over four years. The fourth goal outlined the platform technology design -- exploring collaborative mixed reality(MR) and biometric sensor devices. By integrating these two concepts,  a technology plan was created to simulate virtual hospital scenarios while providing real-time biometric feedback data to assess SEI learning and progress.  The HP Reverb G2 Omnicept edition MR headset and Empatica E4 wristband were identified as viable device candidates. The HP headset would provide both a simulated virtual environment for stakeholders while collecting key biometric data, and the wristband would track biometric data in both the virtual and physical realms of the metaverse. The fifth goal involved completing a  proposal based on the platform. A proposal was submitted to the Smart & Connected Communities (S&CC) program solicitation, NSF-21-535. The feedback received from the proposal provides a substantial basis for a future submission.

Key insights were also gathered from a series of five focus groups and four interviews conducted with RHCA student, RHCA faculty, and MRMC staff. The focus groups confirmed that enhanced SEI skills would be needed by the students to perform required hospital work tasks, that the clinical rotation experience for the students could be both better communicated and integrated, resiliency would improve student motivation, students were ambitious in their career plans, and the general design of the platform was appropriate. Insights from the focus groups and interviews have assisted researchers in determining that the platform will address key community needs.

Students participating in the platform will be supplied with critical work experience and SEI competencies for overall life skills and as they enter the workforce. Educational institutions utilizing the platform will make use of revolutionary and adaptable learning methods that prepare students through VR-based WBL. These new learning methods in conjunction with novel approaches to biometric data collection and assessment have the potential to significantly advance education and provide more opportunities for underserved communities. Through the platform, students can develop positive work relationships with professionals within their desired field of study. These professionals will have the opportunity to assist in developing more resilient and well-prepared future employees for high-demand fields within their expertise. Members from underserved communities participating in the platform will be able to more confidently network with these professionals in fields of interest and attain improved employment opportunities that may not have been previously available. Patients will receive more support and have access to healthcare workers that can confidently communicate with them, empathize with their situation, and correctly assist them with their desired needs. Hospitals and other industries will have access to better prepared workers and potentially reduce turnover. Ultimately, the platform will produce a well-prepared workforce resilient to many situations within modern industries and capable of traversing the ever-expanding metaverse. Such a workforce will aid future national competitiveness across industries that utilize the platform.
